On Saturday, the 19th of August, the house was all sale when I went to bed, which was with in few minutes of twelve o'clock—the fastenings of the house were secure as usual—they were quite safe—the windows were not fastened, but the window in question was down, and the Venetian blind over it—that is a window on the first floor landing-place—it was not fastened, but pushed close down and the blind was down over it—my servant, my baby, and myself were is the house on this night—I went to bed, and heard a noise, as I fancied, about two o'clock—I bum a rush-light, but it was gone into by some means, and I was rather surprised at it—I sat up a little time in bed to listen, and after listening some time I heard a second noise over my head, like the fire-irons falling down—I instantly got out of bed, and gave the alarm—I went down stairs, and into the street, as far as the chapel—I went out at the front of the house—I saw one of the railway policemen—I did not see any person go from the house—as soon as I got hold of the policeman's arm, he supported me, and brought me home—I was confused, and could scarcely see, but when 1 returned to the house I observed the window which had been down was open, and the two back doors I found open—those doors had been secured the night before—I discovered that the house had been robbed—I missed some of my own property—my packets were turned inside out, and empty—they were the pockets which I wore—I missed my purse, with six sovereigns in it, and some silver which I had in my pocket, and every thing which had been in it—they had been on a chair the night before, at the foot of my bed, in my own bed room—I have since seen the purse and some of the property. M'Conachy, Q. Which way did the thieves break into the house? A. I cannot say, but the window was open, and I found the two back doors open—I did not observe that the bolts were broken—nor was the win dow that I know of.

ROSETTA ANN WELLS . I am servant to Mr. Whiffin. On Saturday, the 19th of August, I was sleeping in the house, and about one o'clock I heard a noise—I remained still, and heard it again—I got up—the noise appeared down stairs—I thought at first it was in the parlour—I after wards heard the noise repeated—I then heard it in the kitchen—I got out of bed, listened, and looked over the bannisters on the landing—I saw somebody's hand placed on the bannisters, and a flat candlestick in his and—I could not see who it was—I listened again, as I thought it might I went to bed again, and about a quarter after two o'clock I heard a noise again in the room under me, which is a bed-room, but no body sleep there—about three o'clock, or twenty minutes after, I heard Mrs. Puig—I did not raise any alarm till I heard her—I did not hear her voice—I opened the window and saw her outside—I asked if it was Mrs. puig, and she answered me, and I raised an alarm—my window is at the back of the house—Mrs. Puig went down the garden—I saw a man get up a tree when she was going down the garden—the tree was near the wash

house—I saw another man get up the wall—I then gave an alarm—I did not see what became of the man who got up the tree, as I went down stairs, leaving the window—the railway flags are on the other side of the wall; where the other man was getting up—a person might get from the tree on to the wash-house, through a timber-yard, and on to the rail road—I had seen nothing but the hand and candlestick on the bannisters—that was all I saw at that time—I got into bed after that, and afterwards saw a man come up stairs with a lantern while I was laying in bed—I had put the' door wide open on purpose to listen—he stood on the top stair and looked round—he did not come on the landings—he did not do any thing—he stood there a moment or so—I did not know what to do, whether to say any thing—I closed my eyes for fear his eye should catch mine and turned round and coughed—I saw no more of him—he went down—he did not come on the landing-place—it was about twenty-five minutes after three o'clock when I looked out of the window, and saw Mrs. Puig, and it was about three o'clock when the man came up stairs—I cannot tell who the roan was.

ROBERT LOGAN . I am a policeman in the employ of the London and Greenwich Railway Company. On Sunday morning, the 20th, I was alarmed by a noise from Mr. Whiffin's house, about twenty-five minutes after three o'clock—I saw Mrs. Puig, who said there were thieves in the house—I went in with her, and observed the window on the landing-place open; in consequence of which I endeavoured to see if any one had gone away the back way—Wells gave me information—I went down stairs as quickly as I could, and found the back door open—I went into the garden but did not succeed in finding them—I took one direction, and it turns out that they took another—I found the house very much disturbed, and property disturbed in, I think, three or four rooms—I found a mustard pet by the side of the railway wall; on the railway side of the wall, not on the part which would be Mr. Whiffin's garden—a person getting over from there would be in Mr. Whiffin's ground—it was very near the wall—a man in my presence picked up a pair of spectacles, a few yards from the mustard-pot.

ABRAHAM CURTIS . I am a policeman of the Railroad. On the morning of the 20th of August, about three o'clock, I was alarmed on my best by hearing a female voice 'cry, "Thieves and police"—two people directly came over the wall, not a minute after I heard the voice—it is the boundary-wall of the railway, between the railway and Mr. Whiffin's garden—I endeavoured to take them—one went through the arch, and the other came down the wall directly after—I took the last, who was James M'Conachy—he had only one shoe on—I sprang my rattle, and shortly afterwards Andrews was brought to me—it was not five minutes after the alarm was given before he was in custody—I could not justly identify him as the man who got over the wall—it was not exactly daylight but the moon was shining through the arch—I could tell him by the drew he had on—I found no property on M'Conachy.

EDWARD VINCENT . I am a policeman of the Metropolitan Police. I heard a rattle spring about half-past three on the morning of the 20th of August—I hastened to the spot, and saw a man run from under the arch of the railway—I did not exactly see where he went to—I lost sight of him, and followed the sound of his footsteps to an unfinished house—after waiting less than a minute I saw the prisoner Andrews come from unfinished house, and I apprehended him—when I found Mr. Whiffin's house

had been broken open, I searched him, and found a quantity of plate on him, which I produce; here are 3 table-spoons, 8 tea-spoons, 2 salt spoons, a scent –bottle, 2 bunches of keys, 3 sovereigns, and 3s., in silver, a thimble, and a knife—I found all these in his right hand trowsers pocket—I took him to the station-house—I found a mustard-spoon by the side of the railway wall, by Mr. Whiffin's premises—I did not find any thing else.
Andrews. Q. How long might you have lost sight of me? A. Not. more than a minute.

JAMES CONNOR. I am a policeman. On the morning of the 20th of August, I assisted Vincent in searching Andrews, and I found on him 1 sovereign 3 pencil-cases, 2 cruet-tops, a small scent-box, 1 ear-ring, 1 knife, and 1 small ivory snuff-box—they were in his left-hand trowsers pocket also 2 old shillings, and a 6d., a brooch, a red silk purse, with about 3 1/2 in it, a white silk handkerchief, and a belcher handkerchief.

JOHN WILLIAM RIXON . I am a policeman. On Sunday morning, the 20th, I searched the garden belonging to Mr. Whiffin's houses, about twenty-five minutes after three o'clock, and found a wine-strainer at the end of the wash-house, close under a tree, and also the cruet-stand, and a bunch of keys—I found in the yard, near the spot, a pair of scissors, and under a tree a socket chisel—the tree would lead to the top of the wash-house—I found a knife on M'Conanchy at the station-house, which has not been owned.

JOSEPH WILLIAM CLARK. I am a policeman. On Sunday morning, About half past three o'clock I was near Mr. Whiffin's premises, in the Yard adjoining the house, behind the house—there is another yard beyond That, before you get to the railway—in the yard behind the house I found One great-coat, a silk dress, a dressing-gown, three silk handkerchiefs, and A scarf.

WILLIAM CROXON . I am a police-sergeant. On the same Sunday morning, about half-past three o'clock I went to the garden belonging to Mr. Whiffin, and between then and half-past five o'clock I found a variety of articles, which I produce—a scarf, a pin-cushion, a tobacco stopper, and other articles—I also found a right-foot shoe in a potato garden in Mr. Whiffin's grounds—you would not go through it to get to the railway—it is the corner piece—the railway boundary wall separates the railway from Mr. Whiffin's premises—you would not go that way from the railway to the house—it is an angle, sown with potatoes—a person could get from Mr. Whiffin's premises to the railway by going through the potato ground—that shoe was afterwards shown to M'Conachy, and he said, "Oh, you have got my shot"—I was present when he said so—he then began to pull his stocking over his right toe to have the shoe put on, and said, "Ayn't you going to give me the shoe?"—I said, "No, I must have the other one"—he took his other shoe off, and gave it me—when he said it was his shoe, I said, "Where did you leave it?"—he said, in the potato garden, or in the garden, among the potatoes—I cannot swear which—I did not fit the shoe on him, but I took the other one off, which was the fellow to it—they looked like a pair, and they certainly are a pair of shoes—they are nailed and ironed in the same manner—he asked me what he should do without his shoes—I said he should have a new pair—he asked when, and I said he would have to walk some distance first, and he said he was lucky like me.

HENRY THOMAS DALLEY . I am a police-sergeant. On Monday, the 21st of August, I was in High-street, Shadwell, and saw Moore and Gilles in company with another person—I gave directions to have them looked after—I

Saw Moore, when the constable laid hold of him, drop himself down towards the kennel, and something white, having the appearance of silver, fell from him into the kennel—Gilles and other ran away—a man named Chata way, who is subpœnaed here, came up quickly, put his jacket over it, and walked off with it—I left the other two, and went after Chat away, and took him—I asked what he had there, and he had a pair of plated snuffers in his jacket, under his arm, with mud and filth out of the kennel on them—the jacket appeared just in the same way as when he gathered the things out of the kennel—I afterwards searched Moore, and in his hat found thus blue silk handkerchief, and a crape scarf; on his neck a remnant of silk tied as a handkerchief; and in his pocket, this small knife, attached to a piece of tape, which he was wearing at his button-hole—I apprehended Giles about twenty-five minutes afterwards—the constable took Moore, by my directions I found nothing on Giles belonging to the prosecutor—I asked him what he ran away for—he said, "I did not run away"—he said, "You are welcome to search me; I have nothing about me now"—Mr. Whiffin gave me the leg of the pair of snuffers, which are deficient a leg.
Moore. Q. Did you see me drop down with the snuffers? Witness. A. Yes.
Moore. When he took me to the station-house he said, "why the h—did you not stop that other boy? I think he dropped the snuffers down." Witness. I did not—I am positive it was Moore threw them down.

HENRY WHIFFIN . My house is in the parish of St. Paul, Deptford—(looking at the property)—these spoons are mine—the table and tea spoon, and the others—this wine-strainer is mine—these dresses are my daughter's these snuffers I am positive of by the dent in them—I gave the policeman the leg which had broken off when the snuffers had a fall—this little box is my servant's.

SUSANNAH WHIFFIN . I am the daughter of the last witness—(looking at the articles found on Moore)—this piece of silk, the crape scarf, and hand kerchief are mine—I left them all safe in my drawers in the first floor bed-room—I know the other articles to be my father's and these articles of dress found in the yard I know to be my sister's—they all belong to the family—I know the remnant of silk—I remember it very well.

MRS. PUIG re-examined. This bunch of keys is mine, and the pair of scissors, two pin-cushions, 2 handkerchiefs, and the money—I have no mark on the sovereigns, but I had six in this purse—the silver was loose in my pocket—this white silk handkerchief was in the pocket also, and this handkerchief was in a large box below in the pantry—this small belongs to the servant—I have seen it in the kitchen.

M'Conachy's Defence. On the 19th of August, I left home at half-past two in the afternoon, to walk to Greenwich Park—I crossed the water at Execution-dock—on going down Deptford-road. I fell in Company with a young man, who asked where I was going—I told him—he said he had no work and would walk with me—we came out of the park, and went to a public-house and had some beer—we sat there till half-past eleven o'clock on Saturday night, and started to go home—coming along by the railroad he bid me good night—I thought it was too late to go home, and got over into the garden to go to sleep—I came up to a piece of board where there were some leaves of trees—I awoke about three o'clock, and found one of my shoes off, and a stone had got to my toe—I heard a cry of "stop thief"—I immediately got up and set off, with my shoe in my
hand, and let it fall just over the wall, and the policeman caught hold of me—I know nothing of the robbery.

Andrews' Defence. On the 17th of August I got a job to go to Graves end with a barge, and on the 19th I left Gravesend—on Sunday morning, between three and four o'clock, I was coming through Deptford—two young men were quarrelling—I went to them—they made it up, and I left them—when I got on the top of the railway I heard a rattle spring, a young man put a bundle into my hand, and said, "Run with it"—I ran into the empty house with it, not wishing to be seen with it—I opened it in the house and found the spoons—I came out and was searched, and the property found on me; but I knew nothing of the robbery.

M'CONACHY—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

ANDREWS—
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Death Recorded.

GILES and MOORE—
NOT GUILTY .

2238.
JAMES MOORE and
WILLIAM GILES were again indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Joseph Prendergast, at Lewisham, about two o'clock in the night of the 5th of August, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 flute, value 3l.; and 1 hat, value 2s. 6d., the foods of
Alexander Cavell the younger; and 1 flute, value 5l., the goods of
Joseph Martyn; and that Giles had been before convicted of felony.
MR. PRENDERGAT conducted the Prosecution.

ELIZABETH PRENDERGAST. I am the wife of the Rev. Joseph Prendergast, and live at Lewisham, in Kent. On Saturday, the 5th of August, I saw the house secured before I went to bed—there is a door from the private dining-room—that room where the boys dine—there is a door into the play-ground from that room, and a window towards the gar den I know that window and door were secure—next morning(Sunday)about six o'clock, when our man King came, he gave an alarm—I got up and come down the first—I went into the school-dining-room, and found the window-sash taken wholly out and removed—it is a small window—I inquired for the flutes and violins, and things on that sort, and the man produced some bundles form the play-ground—one bundle contained four flutes, tied in a yellow silk handkerchief, and there was a violin in a green bag—this property had been in the school-dinning-room the night before—the violin was generally kept on the sideboard—there were some shoes ready to be taken away—some outside the window, some in the play ground; and some on the table—they belong to the young gentlemen, who had left them below on Saturday night—they had been moved from where they were the night before—I saw a hat which Joseph Martyn found, and delivered to me, and I gave it to the policeman—there were four flutes—it was broad daylight when I was alarmed.

PETER KING . On the morning of the 6th of August I went to Mr. Prendergast's house, about six o'clock—it was quite light then—I saw two young lads there outside the school-dinning-room—one had got a parcel under his arm, and the other another parcel—they put them down directly, and ran away—I pursued them, but lost them—I saw the bundles after wards in the same place, and picked them up under the window—I put them in at the window—I did not know what was in them—they are the bundles Mrs. Prendergast saw—I saw a violin in one—I saw the sash-window laid against the side of the school-room outside—there were two lads
—one was bigger than the other, but I could not swear to them—I have very little belief about them.

ALEXANDER CAVELL . I am a pupil at Mr. Prendergast's school—I went into the school-room at near eight o'clock on Sunday morning—this flute belongs to me—I found it in the school-dining-room when I came down—I had left it in a box the night before—there was a hat gone belonging to me, which had been in the school-dining-room—the policeman has since produced it to me—-there was a strange hat left behind—the value of my flute is about 3l.
MRS. PRENDERGAST. That is one of the flutes which was handed in at the window by King, in the yellow handkerchief.

JOSEPH MARTYN . I was at the school, and was alarmed about half-past six o'clock, or a quarter to seven—I had a flute in my box the night be fore, locked up in the flute-box—this is it—(looking at it)—when I came down in the morning it was lying on the table—it is worth about 5l—I saw a hat there, with a piece of candle and a black silk handkerchief in it—I gave it to Mrs. Prendergast.

HENRY MUMFORD . I am a constable of Lewisham. In consequence of the alarm I went to the house of Mr. Prendergast—I observed the school dining-room window—it appeared to have been taken out by a chisel—there were traces of a chisel—I received a hat from Mrs. Prendergast, containing the black silk handkerchief and lucifer matches, and a piece of candle—the candle, I think, was not in the hat when it was delivered to me but it was delivered to me by somebody else at the same time—Mrs. Prendergast delivered the lucifer-matches to me with the hat—I have tried the hat on the prisoners, and it will fit Moore.

JAMES WILD (police-constable R 141.) I produce a hat, which I found on Moore's head on Saturday, the 26th of August, when he was in the station-house—I asked him how long he had had it—he said two or three months, and that he bought it of a Jew in Rosemary-lane.

ALEXANDER CAVELL
re-examined. This is my hat—I know it by it's having a half-buckle here—the maker's name was in it, but it is torn off; and there is "water-proof, London," done underneath, where it is torn of—it fits me (trying it on.)

HENRY THOMAS DALLEY . I am a police-sergeant. I apprehend these prisoners on the 21st of August, in the afternoon—I had seen Moore save ral times before—I looked at his hat—on the 21st or 22nd of May last I took it into my band on purpose to examine it; and, to the best of my belief this hat which was left on the premises is the hat—it has every appearance of it—I saw him with this other hat on when I took him into custody, and I made an observation that it was a different hat—I had not then received in formation of this robbery.
moore‘s Defence. He took that old hat to my mother, and wanted her to come to the office and swear it was mine.

MOORE—
GUILTY* of housebreaking and stealing under the value of 5l . Aged 17.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

GILES—
NOT GUILTY .

2239.
ELIZABETH BALL and
ANN CONNOLLY
were indicated for stealing, on the 5th of December, 1 shawl, value 3s. the goods of
William Thomas Hoyes, the master of the said Elizabeth Ball.
ANN HOYES . I am the wife of William Thomas Hoyes, a fisherman in Trafalgar road, Greenwich. The prisoner Ball was a poor girl in distress,

I took her in to bring her up, and tried what I could do to make her comfortable—I gave her every thing which laid in my power, and she be haved very well till Tuesday morning, the 5th of September—when—I got up, and saw a bundle lying at the foot of my bed—I went into the next room, and missed some money from the table and missed my shawl, and Ball was absent—I went with a policeman to Ball's mother, and found the prisoners both together and gave them in charge—I asked Ball what she had done with my shawl—she said she had left it at No. 206, Kent-street—the other said, "Policeman, I will tell you the truth, I stood opposite the house and received the bundle and money from her, and ran away with it"—the money was half-a-crown—the policeman found the shawl—Ball is a relation of mine, and I took her to save her from ruin—her mother it a very notorious character, and I am fearful it is her that has brought her to what she is.

JOHN WALKER (police-constable R 182.) On the 5th of September I was on duty in Trafalgar-road, Greenwich—the prosecutrix came and gave I me a description of the girl—I could not find her till last Sunday, when I found her in Bennett-street, Greenwich, with Connolly and Ball's mother, all three in bed together—I said to the prosecutrix, "Which is your? servant?"—she pointed her out, and asked her where her shawl was—she said, "At 206, Kent-street"—on coming out of the house, Connolly said "Policeman I will tell you the truth, I had the money and the shawl, we spent it between us"—I went to No. 206, Kent-street, and found the shawl pawned for sixpence—Ball said it was true she had taken it—her mother is a very bad woman indeed, and the prisoner was on the tows twelve months ago, and was put into the workhouse.
(Property produced and sworn to,)

BALL
GUILTY . Aged 14.

CONNOLLY
GUILTY . Aged 14
Confined Twelve Months.
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2240.
THOMAS RICHARDSON was indicted
for stealing on the 19th of September, 1 vice, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
John Frederick Wheeler.

JOHN HORTON I know the vice which is now in court—it belong to John Frederick Wheeler, a millwright, who was repairing the Creek bridge, it Greenwich—it was left on the bridge on Monday, the 19th of September—I saw it at half-past six o'clock that evening, and missed it next morning—it had been taken in the course of the night—it was found on the Thursday, I believe, and shown to me—I knew it.

RICHARD SHARWOOD . I am a policeman. On Thursday evening, about a quarter past nine o'clock, I received information that two men we stopped with a vice at Williams's, a pawnbroker's, at Greenwich—I went there, and found two men with it—I asked the prisoner, (who was one of them,) if it was his property—he said it was—I asked where he got it from—he said that was his business—I asked who he worked for—he said that was his business—I examined it, and found it answered the prosecutor's description of it, and detained him.

SARAH WOOD WILLIAMS . My husband keeps a pawnbroker's shop in Trafalgar-road, Greenwich. The prisoner and another man came in about eight o'clock in the evening of the 21st of September, to pawn this vice—I had a description of one being stolen, and asked the prisoner his name—said, "James Old, 24, Thames-street," that he was a lodger,

and it was his own property, that he gave 5 0s. for it, and had had it in his possession five months—I said, "If 1 do not mistake it is stolen, and I roust detain you"—they both of them sat down quite quietly while I went for a policeman—they did not attempt to run away.
ELIZA FORD . The prisoner lodged at ray mother's. On Tuesday morning I was going to make his bed, and saw this vice in the bed-room—he worked at the Phoenix Gas Works.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

2241.
JEREMIAH FOSTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of August, 1lb. weight of mutton, value 9d.; and 1/2lb. weight of sum value 4d.; the goods of
Abraham George Owen, the younger.
MR. CURWOOD conducted the Prosecution.

ABRAHAM GEORGE OWEN . I live at Lewisham, and am a butcher I have seen the prisoner come to my shop several times for the last six months—I lost this mutton about ten o'clock on Sunday morning, the 20lb August—the prisoner then came to my shop for some meat—there was another customer in the shop—I went to weigh some meat for that person—I had suspicion of the prisoner, and I looked at the meat I had in the shop before he came in—when I turned my head from the scale I mind a piece of mutton, and told him I thought he had got it—he said he had not got it—several persons were in the shop—he stopped a short time then said, "Good morning, "and went away—I sent for the constable, and told him I suspected the man over the road had got some mutton of mine—in went, and brought the prisoner in, with a bit of breast of mutton resembling that I had lost—he had bought some mutton, a piece of a breast.

WILLIAM SUMPTER . I live in Reed-place, East Greenwich which is a mile and a quarter from Mr. Owen. I was at Lewisham that Sunday waiting for the Maidstone coach, and there I saw the prisoner not further from the prosecutor's than from here to Ludgate-hill—he had another man with him—I saw something drop, and called after them—I told them they were leaving their dinner behind—they turned off the footpath to come to me, and the prisoner said, "Will you swear that I dropped that meat?"—I said I could as safely swear I saw him drop that bit as I did the last (I saw two pieces drop from the prisoner)—the constable came and asked me if I would walk back to the. shop, and he took the two bits of meat—he had the roan in his charge at the time, and he took them back to the shop—I wont with them—Mr. Owen began to say something about some one—he said he thought this man had got it, and he would search him—the prisoner said, no, he should not—the constable searched him, and found about half a pound of suet in his pocket—Mr. Owen said that suet belonged to him—the prisoner said he had bought some suet of him—l believe there was an argument about some small quantity being bought.

ABRAHAM GEORGE OWEN
re-examined. I believe this is the piece I thought I lost—I cannot swear to it—1 sold him one piece of breast only missed one—the piece he bought was given up to his wife.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Did you charge him with having stolen any suet? A. No—I did not know that I had lost any—when the officer searched him and found the suet I claimed it—I will swear I did not admit that he had bought it—he did not buy a morsel of suet—if the officer has sworn it is wrong.
JOHN WOOLLARD . I am an officer. I remember on the Sunday morn

ing the prosecutor said he had lost-some meat—he showed me the prisoner—I overtook him, and told him I wanted him on an unthankful piece of business—I said, "You must go back with me"—when we were coming back he dropped the piece of meat—I did not see that—Sumpter called, and said, "You have dropped some of your dinner," and then we turned round and I saw this on the ground—somebody in the crowd gave it to me—I went to the butcher's shop—the prisoner said the meat did not belong to Mr. Owen, for all he had got he paid for—he had a bit of breast of mutton in his handkerchief, which has been given to his wife—Mr. Owen said he had not bought any suet of him, and then the prisoner all but acknowledged he had not bought it—he first said he had bought it, and then Mr. Owen said he had not—the meat picked up and given to me corresponded with the description that Owen gave me.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he not go willingly with you? A. Yes. (The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 22. Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor .
Confined Two Months; Two Weeks Solitary.

2243.
Mary M'GEAREY was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of September, 1 copper scale, value 5s., the goods of
William Downard.

SARAH ANN DOWNWARD . I am the wife of William Downard, and live in New-row, Deptford. I knew the prisoner—she occasionally used the shop—I missed this scale on Wednesday, the 13th of September, between six and nine o'clock—I had seen it before that day—I had not seen the prisoner on that day at our shop, that I know of.

WILLIAM COLLINGS (police-sergeant R 18.) I found the scale on a lending above the room where the prisoner lived—I went there in con sequence of information that a boy had offered a scale for sale—the boy was the prisoner's son—he was taken before the Magistrate but not com mitted—we followed him to a house in New-row, and asked him where the scale was, and we went into the room which the prisoner occupied—we asked her if she knew any thing of the scale—she said "No"—we searched the room, and there was nothing there—I then went up stairs and there found it.

BENJAMIN LOVEL (police-sergeant R 15.) I took the prisoner on, Friday, the 15th, and in going to the station-house she said she would clear the boy—that she took it through distress to get bread for the children—the boy was not seen with it—he went and asked at the mariane store shop if they would buy such a thing.
Prisoner. I was coming by this woman's door between six and seven o'clock—I picked up the scale, and being in distress I brought it home tog et some victuals for the children.
NOT GUILTY .

2244.
JOHN THOMAS was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of August, 1 ass, price 2 0s., the property of
Joseph Marsh.

SARAH MARSH . I am the wife of Joseph Marsh, and live in Drogmore-lane Streatham, surrey. I had an ass safe on the 18th of August in my yard—it was turned out about half-past eight o'clock., on Thursday, for feeding in the land—I have seen it since—it was found at Lewisham by the constable—the Magistrate at Greenwich gave it me.
THOMAS SMITH . I went after the ass, and found it at the house of Mr. Perren, near Lewisham-bridge—the prisoner's house is nearly
opposite—I went with the constable and asked him about it—he said he had sold Mr. Perren the ass, and had changed it for another donkey and a shilling.
ABRAHAM PERREN . I am a donkey driver—I bought the donkey of the prisoner on the 18th of August—I gave him another one for it and a shilling.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought that donkey on the 18th of August between Lewisham and Sydenham, of Thomas Martin, a man with a sear on his left cheek—I gave him 15s. and a pot of half and half for it—it was not big enough for me, and I sold it to Mr. Perren—the Magistrate's clerk said that he knew Martin—that he was a noted donkey stealer, but we could not find him.
GUILTY .

2245.
JOHN THOMAS was again indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of August, 1 ass, price 2 0s., the property of
John East.

EDMUND EAST . I am the son of John East, a letter carrier. He had a donkey—on the 8th of August I turned it out on Clapham Common—her name is Fanny—she knows me when I speak to her—she held up her head to me—she has a notch on her tail—I saw her again at Mr. Puck eridge's stable, and knew her again—she held out her head to me.
JAMES ABBOTT . I am a shoemaker. On the 9th of August I saw the prisoner driving a donkey—I knew Fanny—it looked like her—I knew the prisoner before.
JAMES PUCKERIDGE . I bought the donkey of the prisoner for 5s., and another donkey.
Prisoner. I am very sorry for what has happened about this one—I am not guilty of the other.
GUILTY . Aged 26.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined Six Months; Six Weeks Solitary.

2246.
MARY WHITTICK was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of September, 1 sovereign, 1 half-crown, 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence; the monies of
Samuel Martin, from his person.

SAMUEL MARTIN . I am a broker, and live at No. 4, Union-street Woolwich. On the 16th of September, about twelve o'clock, I was going home, and met the prisoner in High-street—she asked where I was going,—I said, "Home"—she followed me through the gardens, and wanted me to go with her—I told her no, I had got a wife of my own at home—she followed me to a corner, and would not let me go away, and then she put her hand into my pocket, took the money and ran away—I had a sovereign, a half-crown, a shilling, and a sixpence—I followed her—she turned a comer and I lost sight of her—I went to a public-house and saw her—I asked for my money—she said she had not got it—I called the watchman and told him what I had lost—he took her to the station—she was very rough, and refused to be searched by any but a woman—they said they would be very decent with her—the sovereign, half-crown, shilling, and sixpence were found on her,
WILLIAM GREEN . I am a watchman. I took the Prisoner to the watch-house—the prosecutor told me directly what he had lost—I found this money in the prisoner's left boot.

Prisoner's Defence. I was in the Coach and Horses and the prosecutor was there—I came out, and he came and asked me to go home with him I went up the gardens with him—he said, if I would go further he would

give me a shilling—he went on, and gave me 1s. 4d., and I came away—he came after me and said I had robbed him of 1l. 4s.—I never wore a pocket—I had had the money ever since Thursday—I had 2l. 15s., and spent 1l., and had 1l. 15s. left—I gave a young man 10s., and had 1l. 4s. left.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months; Six Weeks Solitary.
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2247.
WILLIAM FRANCIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of May, 1 pair of shoes, value 6s., the goods of
William Davis and another; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

2248.
HARRIET COLLIER was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of September, 1 bag, value 1d.; 1 half-crown, 10 shillings, and 1 sixpence; the goods and monies of
Joseph Parsons.

JOSEPH PARSONS . I am a pensioner of Greenwich. I got drunk last "ale day," about four o'clock, I think—I had been sober before—I had seen my money before four o'clock—I had 15s. in my little bag, a half-crown, and sixpence, and an old sixpence, which I picked up about four years ago—I know it again—this is it (looking at it)—I found myself lying in a bed, and the policeman came and awoke me—my money was gone—I do not know that I had been with any woman that night.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How old are you? A. Seventy nine—it was not my own bed I found myself in—I was put into the bed, as I was drunk—I cannot tell what I did.

WILLIAM DYKE (police-constable R 100.) I received some information that induced me to go after the old man—I found the prisoner at the bar in bed with him—I left the house for some time, and about an hour after I met the prisoner going from Greenwich towards Deptford—I said, "Where are you going, my lass?"—"To Deptford," said she, "and I came from Woolwich"—I said, "You must have made a quick passage; I saw him in bed with the pensioner"—she said, "I left him; I did not like to stop with so old a man"—I said, "What money have you got about you?"—she said, "Only one shilling"—I said, "I am afraid you have been doing the old man, as the other one did before; I shall search"—I found another shilling, a sixpence, and a halfpenny—I said, "Where did you get this?"—said she, "To tell you the truth, I have taken it from the pensioner"—I told her I should take her to the station-house—in going along I saw she wanted to shift something—I saw her going to throw something into the road—I caught hold of her by the hand, and said, "What have you got here?"—she said, "I don't know"—I said, "It is a purse, or something like it; where did you get it?"—she said, "I took that out of the pensioner's pocket likewise"—there was a half-crown, ten shillings, a sixpence, and an old piece of silver in it, which the pensioner has identified.

Cross-examined. Q. What time was it that you found these two in bed together? A. Between twelve and one o'clock in the morning—the prosecutor was sitting at the side of the bed, wide awake—the woman was undressed, and laying on the bed—I did not know her at all—I never saw her, to my knowledge—I was in the room from a quarter of an hour to twenty minutes—I have been on that station these last seven years.
NOT GUILTY .

2249.
ROBERT JOHN ARNOLD was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of September, 1 shilling, the money of
Joseph Davis and another his masters.

JOSEPH DAVIS . I am a pawnbroker, and live at Woolwich—I am in partnership with Lewis Davis—the prisoner was my apprentice. On the 2nd of September I found in his coat pocket, which was in his box, one sovereign, one crown, nine half-crowns, and four shillings—I put it back, and my shopman marked some money.

CHARLES SOLOMON JACOBS . I am the prosecutor's shopman. I marked two shillings, and placed them on a ledge over the till, on Saturday morning, the 2nd of September, about eleven o'clock—about four o'clock I missed one—it was found in the prisoner's pocket, by Mr. Davis and my self—this is one of the shillings—I said nothing to the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What was this boy? A. As apprentice—he never took in pledges—his duty was to keep the pledges in order in the warehouse—they want moving about continually—he has never taken in pledges, to my knowledge—I have been absent, and let him in the shop—if Mr. Davis was not in the shop, the prisoner was in call some one.
THOMAS CHITTENDEN . I am a Woolwich police-constable. I took the prisoner, and have the shilling.

JOSEPH DAVIS
re-examined. The prisoner had no authority to receive pledges, but to receive money for goods that were sold—he might have had the opportunity of taking the shilling in giving change—he had as access to the till—he ought to have come to me, or our shopmen and asked for change—I was in town between eleven and four o'clock, on the 2nd of September—I cannot tell who was there that the prisoner might go to—the ledge is the general place where money is put for things that were sold—for change he would go to the pledge-counter, and ask the young men for it—he had a right to go there.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.
Confined Three Months; Three Weeks Solitary.

2250.
JOSEPH CLARKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of September, 1 shirt, value 3s. 6d.; and 1 jacket, value 4s. 6d.; the goods of
Samuel Hitchcock.

JONATHAN SHEPHERD . I am a policeman. I was on duty on the 17th of September, at Deptford, at half-past one o'clock in the morning and saw the prisoner on the road, near Deptford-bridge, about 300 yards from the prosecutor—my suspicions were attracted by seeing something bulky in his pocket—I asked him what he had got in his pocket—he said, "Some things"—I asked what—he said "A shirt and jacket," and he had bought them where he was hopping, below Westerham—I asked him to let me see them—he put the shirt out—I saw it was tumbled and took him to the station-house—I made inquiry, and found the owner as the Monday.
SAMUEL HITCHCOCK . I am a slop-seller and out-fitter, and live is Broadway, Deptford. This is my property—it was taken from inside my shop on the Saturday evening—I had seen it about ten o'clock.
Prisoner. I was not in the shop at all.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

2251.
MARY CHARLTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of. September, 1 crown-piece, the money of
Thomas Adams, from his person.

THOMAS ADAMS . I went down to an acquaintance at Greenwich, and on coming back, I called at the Ship and Last, and saw this prisoner—she said she was in distress—I said, "I don't like to see any body in distress, if I had a copper I would give you half"—we had two or three pints of half-and-half, and then I said we would have something to eat, and we went from thence towards the Fortune of War, but on the road I took her into a cook-shop, and said, "What will you like to eat?"—we had five pennyworth of roast pork, and she put it in a paper—I said to her," Why don't you eat it?"—she said, "I don't like to eat it now"—thinks I, you want something to drink, and we went into the Fortune of War, and then called for a pint of beer—I went to pay, and missed a crown out of my pocket—I said to her," Halloo, this is not the thing; you put down that crown-piece again"—"I, "said she," I have no crown at all."—the policeman came up, and I gave her into custody, and in going along by the church at Greenwich, the crown dropped from her—I was a little astart of them, but I heard it.

ROBERT HILL (police-constable K 184.) I took the prisoner—in going along, she dropped the crown—she took it up again and gave it me, and said a woman in distress would do any thing. Prisoner. He laid his hands on me, and made me no recompense.

THOMAS ADAMS
re-examined. No—what I have stated is nothing but the truth—she took hold of my arm—I did not take hold of her—I told her, As you are so hard up, if you can get a night's lodging, I will pay for it"—that is all.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months; Six Weeks Solitary.

2252.
SARAH EDWARDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of August, 3 sheets, value 4l. 10s.; 1 table-cloth, value 6s.; and 1 hand kerchief, value 6d.; the goods of
Mary Anne Hill; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

2253.
SUSAN WATMORE was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of October, 1 table-cloth, value 2s.; 1 flat-iron, value 8d.; and 1 sheet, value 4s.; the goods of
Thomas Grubb.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
John Thomas Grubb; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

ELIZADETH GRUBB . I am the wife of John Thomas Grubb, and live in Garratt-lane, Wandsworth. I lost these articles in October, 1836—1 missed the iron on a Saturday—I cannot say the day of the month—I asked the prisoner if she had taken it—she denied all knowledge of it—I did not miss the sheet and table-cloth till November—the prisoner lived with a man named Williams, in the next house to me—I took the officer to Muggeridge, the pawnbroker, in August last, where I saw the property.
WILLIAM MUGGERIDGE . I am a pawnbroker, and live at Tooting. I produce a table-cloth, which was pawned on the 26th of October, and a
flat-iron on the 22nd in the name of Ann Williams, Garrett-lane—I do not know who by—I know the prisoner as a customer.

ELIZABETH GRUBB
re-examined The prisoner told me where to find the property—I said it would be better if she would own to the truth of it.
NOT GUILTY .

2254.
MICHAEL M'KEW and
SILVESTER FLOOD were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September, 117 yards of bed-tick, value 5l., 16s., the goods of
William Dickenson.

JAMES TIDMARSH . I am a policeman. In consequence of information I received from Williams on the 8th of September, I watched a house in the Maze, at South walk, from half-past nine o'clock till about half-past eleven at night, when I saw two men come out—we let them pass us, and a third person came out, which was M'Kew—we took him into custody, and went into the house, and found this property in a room there—the other two men did not answer the description we had received of the men—Flood was one of those two.

RICHARD WILLIAMS . I am a steam-boiler-maker, and live in Queen street, King-street, Borough. On the 8th of September, between nine and ten o'clock, I saw two men and a woman come from under an arch of London-bridge—M'Kew was one of them—he had a parcel on his shoulder—I followed them down to the church, in Tooley-street, and lost sight of them by the side of the rail-road—I gave information to the officer—the paper round the parcel was torn, and I could see by the gaslight that it was bed-ticking—I cannot speak to Flood—he wore a cap similar to the other man, but I thought the man was shorter than him. SUSANNAH MULHEEN. One Catherine Flood lodged with me in the Maze. On the 8th of September, about ten o'clock, the prisoners came to the house—the woman was out at the time—when she came in she saw bundle when she went up stairs, and she said to the prisoners, "Who brought it here? it will do none of us any good, take it out, or I will throw it into the cart-road"—M*Kew had brought it in—I did not hear them make her any answer.
M'Kew, The other man was coming along, and picked it up—being rather tired, he asked me to carry it, and I did, and the policeman caught me at the corner of the court.

WILLIAM DICKENSON. ' I have not the least doubt of this bed tick being my property—I sent a quantity of bed-tick to a wharf, on Friday the 8th of September, on the Southwark side of London-bridge, very near the arch—it was worth 5l. 16s.,—this is the quantity within two yards, and the package is the same—it has the direction on it which mine had, and the man who packed it is here.
GEORGE WARREN . I packed up this bed-tick—the direction is my writing—it belongs to Mr. Dickenson.

JOHN HOLMES . I live in White's-alley, Coleman-street. I carried the parcel to the wharf, and left it at the wrong wharf—I think I left it is the care of Flood, but I am not certain—it was to go to Canterbury. Flood. I am sure I did not receive it from him or any man—I picked it up in the street.

GEORGE HAVILL (police-constable M 2.) I found the parcel at Mulheen's house, in the back room, first floor—it was cut up into thirteen pieces, and this paper with the direction on it was with it—part of the property had a strap round it—in carrying it to the station-house flood said
he found it near Fenning's wharf, and acknowledged the strap to be his—I had seen the prisoners come out of the house.

M'Kew. I delivered it at a house, by Flood's desire, and immediately I came down the officer collared me. Witness. We heard them tearing it up as we were standing outside the house—they were there two hours before they come out.
MRS. MULHEEN re-examined. They were in the house from ten o'clock till the officer took them—I was at home took them—I was not present when they tore the stuff up.
FLOOD. I was at home and in bed when I was taken.

GEORGE HAVILL
re-examined. We allowed him to pass, not suspecting him—I had seen him before, and thought him a hard working man—I apprehended him in bed in Bull-court.(Flood received a good character.)

M'KEW—
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

FLOOD—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined Six Months.
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2255.
GEORGE WILKINSON, alias Bevan
, was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of August, 1 Handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
John Beeton, from his person.

JOHN BEETON . I am in the employ Messrs. Ballard. On the 25th of August I was near St. George's Church, Southwark, at three o'clock in the afternoon—a female said my pocket was picked—I turned round and saw the prisoner—he took my handkerchief out of his pocket and gave it to me, when I charged him with picking my pocket—he turned his head and saw me when I was about four yards from him, and he took it out and gave him to an officer.
WILLIAM LEWIS KETCHER . I am an officer. I took him into custody.

Prisoner's Defence. I left home about three o'clock to go to my uncle's—I saw two boys going along—they ran away and dropped the handkerchief—I took it up and put it into my pocket—the gentleman immediately came up and gave me in charge.

JOHN BEETON
re-examined. I did not see any boys run away—the prisoner was the nearest to me.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

2256.
JOHN COOPER was indicted
for embezzlement, to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

2257.
JOHN WOOD was indicted
for embezzlement; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .
Confined Three Months.
Before Mr. Justice Vaughan.

2258.
JOHN WEBSTER was indicted
for violating
Mary Hannah Sims, a girl under ten years of age.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. sergeant Arabin.

2259.
JOHN WEBSTER was again indicted
for assaulting the same
Mary Hannah Sims with intent to violate her.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Two Years; Three Months Solitary.

2260.
SARAH GRIFFITHS was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August, knives, value 16s.; and 6 forks, value 8s.; the goods of
William Holmer, her master, and another; and
MARY ANN CADWALLADER
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been Stolen; to which Cadwallader pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 21.

(She received a good character, and was recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.)
Confined Seven Days.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM LAWLEY . I keep a general sale shop in parsonage-row, Newington. On the 20th of August, between seven and eight o'clock, the prisoner Cadwallader came to my shop and offered six ivory handled knives and forks for sale, which I now produce—they are quite new, and of a very superior description—the name of Holmer and Shepherd are on the blades—she asked me 7s. 6d. for them—I knew that was nothing like their value, and sent for a constable immediately—Clarke came in, and I left her and confronted with Cadwallader—she said, "Mary Ann, what I have given you?—speak the truth—I have only given you half a dozen knives and forks, which you were to return if you did not approve of them"—I had these knives and forks in my hand in her presence at the time.

JOSEPH CLARKE . I am a policeman. I was in Newington-road—I received information, and went to Lawley's shop—Cadwallader was delivered into my custody—Lawley left the house to get Grifflths leaving me alone with Cadwallader—while he was gone, she said confusion lived at Mr. Holmer's and apprehended Griffiths, and after they had been confronted together, I took them to the station-house—Cadwallader gave me the key of her lodging, and said I should find a metal tea-pot there, which the cook had given to her—I heard Griffiths say to her, "Why, Mary Ann, I only gave you half a dozen knives and forks"—When I took Griffiths into custody, I told her the charge—she said she know nothing about it—I said she must go with me, and as she went along she took my arm, and said, "What shall I do? Tell me what to do," I said, "Tell me nothing or it will be given in evidence"—she said "I will tell the truth, I did give her the knives—I have got two sovereigns in my pocket, which I will give you to let me go and tell master I go away.
Griffith's. I did not offer him any thing on the sort. Witness. On my soleman oath, she made me the offer three or four times.

SARAH TOWNSEND . I am at the station house, in Towel-street, Westminster-road, to search female prisoners. I searched Griffiths on this occasion, and found two sovereigns, and 18d. in Silver, on her—she said she had taken a dozen knives and forks to give to a young woman, to how somebody and to bring them back, but she never brought them, and in what account she feared she found betransported.

WILLIAM HOLMER . I carry on business in the iron trade, in Union-street, through in partnership with Mr. Shepherd. About Christmas last I took Griffiths into my service—I have two daughters and a son at home, and an
elderly lady who has resided with me ten or twelve years—I do not now live with Mrs. Holmer—I have seen the articles in question—they are my property.
Q. On your solemn oath, did you ever take any liberty with Griffiths? A. Never in my life, so help me God—I never came in contact with her breath in my life, to my knowledge.

Griffiths. I mean to say I have received property from Mr. Holmer and the young ladies several times. Witness. I never gave her any property—I am scarcely ever at home—business takes me eight or nine months a year from home on journeys—I never gave her any thing—my daughters reside with me—one is twenty-four years old, and the other seventeen, and my son is just of age.
CHARLES HOLMER . I am the prosecutor's son, and live at his house. I never gave Griffiths any articles of any description—I never took any liberties with her.
Griffiths. The things I am accused of have been given to me at different times.

GRIFFITHS—
GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.
(There were other indictments against the prisoner.)
Before Mr. Justice Patteson.

2160.
CHARLES THOMPSON and
JOHN SAUNDERS were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August, at St. Giles, Camberwell, 1 watch, value 21l.; and 1 guard chain, value 1l.; the goods of
John Macalaster Houston, in the dwelling-house of
Richard George Fletcher.
MR. STURGEON Conducted the Prosecution.

ANN FLETCHER . I live at Eden House, Albany-road, Camberwell, in the parish of St. Giles, Camberwell, and am the wife of Richard George Fletcher. On Tuesday, the 29th of August, the prisoners came after my apartments—I showed them to them—they approved of them very much, and came down stairs, and said they should wish to return to measure the room for a carpet—I am sure they are the person—I showed them the back bedroom up stairs—they came down, and wished to go up again to measure the room—they both went up with me to measure the corner of the room, to see if it would take a large chest—I took hold of one end of the string, and Saunders took hold of the other end—while I was doing so, the tallest prisoner (Thomson) went out of that room into the other room, belonging to Mr. Houston, who lodged with us—they then came down stairs, and wished to see the way about down stairs—I showed them which way the garden went, and then they went out, and said they would come the next day, but they did not—I saw them again at Lambeth –street Office in custody—I saw the watch in the front room while they were talking to me—there was a silver guard-chain to it—Thompson went into the front room—I missed it directly they were gone—the guard-chain was shown to me at the office.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Which do you call the tallest man? A. The one this way (Thompson)—I fancy him to be the tallest, but that is the one I mean—the watch was there while they were talking to me, until they went up the second time—when they left the gate they ran, but I did not know any thing was wrong till I went up stairs—they said they lived in Albany-street, Regent-street, but did not say the number—I know the watch-chain—I had seen it before—I have seen my lodger wear it, and have looked at it—it is a common silver guard-chain.

Prisoner Thompson. Q. You went up stairs with us? A. Yes—I did not say the house was all in confusion—I said it was undergoing repair—I came down stairs with you and went up again with you both—I did not leave you sitting in the back parlour while I went up with the other—you went up with me too.
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Did not you pay more attention to the taller one than the other? A. I did not pay more attention to one than another.
Thompson. Q. How many workmen had you in your house at the time? A. One painter, that is all—he was painting the front room down stairs, not the room the watch was in.
MR. STURGEON. Q. Did the painter come to you again to finish his job? A. He is with us now, and is a very honest young man.

JOHN MACALASTER HOUSTON . I left my watch at my lodging at the prosecutrix's house, Eden Cottage—in the afternoon I received a note from Mr. Fletcher about it—it was worth from 15l. to 20l.—it was gold—it was given to me by my father, who told me he paid 30l. for it—I have since seen a silver chain which was attached to it—I missed it on the 29th of August.
CHARLES PEGG . (A policeman produced the chain, but the witness having remained in Court after the witnesses were desired to leave, was not examined.)

MR. HOUSTON re-examined. The chain is mine—I have been in the habit of handling it for six years every day, and believe it to be mine—I saw it last on the morning of the 29th of August, attached to the watch; which was under my pillow when I left.

THOMPSON—
GUILTY . Aged 37.

SAUNDERS—
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Life.

2161.
CHARLES THOMPSON and
JOHN SAUNDERS were again indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August, at St. James, Clerkenwell, 1 watch, value 6l.; 1 watch-ribbon, value 3d.; and 1 watch-key, value 3d.; the goods of
Ann Huson, in her dwelling-house.

ANN HUSON . I am a widow, and live in Smith-street, Northampton street, in the parish of St. James, Clerkenwell. On the 28th of August the two prisoners came to my house to take a loding—they looked over the house with my niece, and after that they called me, they said they were satisfied with them, and gave me a reference to No. 13, Catherine-street, Strand—Thompson wrote it in my presence—they gave their names as Johnson, and said they were brothers—this is the address they gave me—(read,) "Mr. Johnson, 13, Catherine-street, Strand; from John, a quarter before six"—I was to call at a quarter to six o'clock to see a brother of theirs, as they said—I showed them out of the house—I think it was a little after four o'clock when they left—I left my house to go to Catherine-street about twenty minutes after five o'clock—I left my watch hanging over the back parlour mantel-piece when I went away—I saw it hanging there not a minute before I went out—I returned a little after eight o'clock—I found no such person in Catherine-street as they referred to—about a quarter of an hour after I returned, I went into the parlour to wind up the watch, and it was gone—I do not know the value of it—my husband said he gave eight sovereigns for it—it was a silver double cased one.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. I suppose you have had it a number of years? A. Yes. a great many, and set a great value on it, as

It was my husband's—I have had it twenty years, probably—I always had it in my possession—it was a very excellent-going watch—Thompson treated with me the most—I took less notice of the other than him—I had never seen them before—I had not much to say to Saunders—he did not talk so much as the other, but I saw them both—there was no one in the house but my niece, myself, and my son, who came in to tea, and went out again—when I went out I left no one at home but my son and my niece.

ELIZABETH SWAINSON . I am the prosecutrix's niece, and live with her. On the 28th of August the two prisoners came about the lodging—I showed them about the house—they went up stairs and when they came down, I took them into the rooms on the ground-floor, and also called my aunt, when they wished to see her—she was on the top of the kitchen stairs when I called her—they saw her in the front-parlour—they did not go into the back-parlour at all—they afterwards left the house, and my aunt went out for a reference—she left about twenty minutes after five o'clock, and the prisoners returned about six o'clock—I cannot say which was the first that spoke to me, but they asked me if my aunt had re turned—I told them she had not—they then asked me if I was sure she was gone to the Strand—I said I was sure she was—Thompson then asked me to lend him a pen and ink to write a note with, as he had seen his brother since he called—I asked them into the front-parlour, and told him the pen and ink was there which he had had in the afternoon to write the address with—they went there, and the pen and ink had been taken away—I asked them to take seats, and went into the kitchen—I left them standing—when I came back with the pen and ink, one was standing on the front-parlour mat, and the other just inside the door—Thompson said he would not write now, he was going as far as Islington, and would return again in half an hour—he asked me if I thought my aunt would ride home, or whether she was sure to come straight home—I said I did not know whether she was sure to come straight home—I said I did not know whether she would ride, but she was sure to come straight home—he them said, if my aunt came back before they returned, and was satisfied with the reference, she might expect their trunks to-morrow morning by ten o'clock—they went away—no one else had been in the house after my aunt went away—I had opened the door to no one but the prisoners—my cousin was at tea with me, but he went out at a few minutes to six o'clock, and I was then alone in the house, and no one else came in.

Cross-examined. Q. Which do you call Thompson? A. They stated at the police-office that one was named Thompson and the other Saunders, but at our house they both gave their names as Johnson, and wrote it on a paper—the one who asked me for the pen and ink was Thompson, and he was the one I had the conversation with about my aunt—I had no particular conversation with the other, only as I was showing them the apartment, he observed about the drawers and other things, about their being new drawers, and other things—I had seen the watch at four o'clock, hanging up on a screw, as I was taking them down stairs to see the apartments—that was the last time I had seen it—I never went into the parlour, after my aunt went out, till the prisoners came again—I did not go into the back-parlour with them, only into the front—I never noticed the watch while they were there then—I never thought of it, not suspecting them—I am sure no one else came in—I am quite sure I never
opened the door, and there was never a knock from the time my aunt left—we were at tea in the kitchen—I am quite sure there was no knock.

THOMPSON—
GUILTY .

SAUNDERS—
GUILTY of stealing under the value of £5.
(There were three other indictments against the prisoners.)
Before Mr. Recorder.

2162.
NOAH GREEN was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of September, 56lbs. of clover hay, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Charles Barclay and others, has masters; and
THOMAS THORN
for feloniously receiving the said goods, well known it to have been stolen; against the Statute, ✗.

JOHN SEDGER . (police-constable R 130.) I was on duty on the 18th of September in Old Kent-road—I saw the prisoner Green driving three horses with a dray—he drove them up to the front of the Prince of Sare Coburg stables—he went to the tap, and had some refreshment with the ostler—he then walked to the dray, and took a quantity of clover-hay to the stable door—I saw Thorn receive it, and take it into the stable—Green then drove the dray on—I followed him till he got opposite the station-house in Black heath-road, and there I took him—I told him it was for stealing a quantity of hay, and at the station-house he said it was only half a truss of hay when he brought it from the farm, and it was usual to leave it for the horses when they returned—I said I believed it was more than half a truss—he still said it was to bait his horses on their re turn, and was set at liberty—I saw the sergeant, and went with him to the Prince of Saxe Co-burg—Thorn was standing outside the door—I called him aside, and said "I have received information that you have some hay left by Barclay and Perkins' man this morning"—he said, "No"—I said, "I have received information that two men have left some here belonging to Barlclay and Perkins"—he said, "No"—I said, "Are you sure of that?"—he said, "Yes"—he went into the stable where a horse was feeding, took from the rack some hay similar to this, and said, "That is all the hay I have got in the stable"—I said, "Is it possible that Barclay and Perkins' men could have left hay here without your knowing it?"—he said, "They could not"—the sergeant went to the next stable, and I followed—he said, "Is this it"—I went to the bottom of the stable, and saw a truss of clover bay apparently the same as I had seen taken in—I brought it out at the stable door, and said, "What is this?"—Thorn said, "It is mine"—I said, "Where did you but it?"—he said, "I bought it"—I said, "Did you pay for it?"—he said, "No"—I said, "Who did you buy it of?"—he said, "A man who has a bit of hay at different times when he called left this hay to pay me for what he had had"—I asked if he knew the man or his employer? he said, "No"—I have brought a sample of the hay here.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Was the hay weighed? A. Yes The public-house is nearly three miles from London-bridge, rather nearer Deptford than London—I was on duty in my uniform—Green had admitted at the station-house that he had left it—I told Thorn I had received in formation some had been left—I was on the other side of the way when I saw Green take the truss into the stable—there is a wide space of ground in front of the house—I do not swear that this is the hay I saw taken in—Green was liberated at the station-house, and went on to Welling, which is thirteen miles from town, and he was taken again on his return.
Cross-examined by MR. JERNINGHAM. Q. At what period was it you spoke to Thorn? A. When he was sitting in front of the tap—I was near the stable—I told him I had received information that Barclay
and Perkins's men had left some hay there—he said they had not—I said, "Are you positive they have not?"—he said, "Yes," and took me into the stable.

GEORGE HERRING (police-sergeant R.) I was at Deptford on the 18th of September, in the Broadway, and went to the Saxe Coburg public-house with Sedger—Thorn was on a bench in front of the house—we called him aside, and asked if he had received any hay from two men belonging to Barclay and Perkins—(Green is in their employ)—I went the same evening to New Cross, and saw Green coming with a dray—I asked if he belonged to that dray—he said he did—I said he must go along with me—he said, "What is to become of my horses and dray?"—I said, "I have seen some of your firm, and have brought a man to take care of the dray"—he said, "You will allow me to speak to him"—I said, "certainly," and he did so—he then asked me on what charge I took him into custody—I said on suspicion of disposing of a truss of hay belonging to his employers, and that he had better not say anything to me about it, as he would come before a Magistrate—he said he had nothing to say, but what he had stated at our station that morning.

JOHN FREEMAN . I am horse keeper to Barclay and Perkins. It is usual for men going any distance to take out hay with them—I did not see whether Green took any out—I recollect when the dray went away, turning round and seeing some on the dray—it is usual to take hay when going as far as Welling, and the quantity I saw.
NOT GUILTY .

2163.
JAMES COLLINS,
MARY COLLINS , and
PETER KIRTLAND were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of August, 1 sovereign, and 6 half-crowns, the monies of
Julia Sophia Beattie.

JULIA SOPHIA BEATTLE . I now reside in Waterloo-road. On the 22nd of August I lived with Mrs. Glenister, at Lambeth—Mrs. Collins fetched me out of Mrs. Glenister's room into hers, which was the next door—I took out my money to send for something to drink, and gave Kirtland half-a-crown to get some gin and beer—I had one sovereign and six half-crowns in my purse then Mrs. Collins once or twice felt my pocket, but she did not take the money out herself I heard Eliza Glenister say she would not have it, but I heard no further—James Collins and Kirtland took me into the adjoining room, where Kirtland's wife laid asleep; and Kirtland held me by the arm, while Mr. Collins put his hand into my pocket, and took out 1l. 15s—Mrs. Collins was not in the room at the time, she was in the other room, holding Mrs. Glenister down there to prevent her coming to help me.
JAMES COLLINS . Q. Is there not a party wall between the two rooms? I think there is—Kirtland's wife laid on the floor—I saw nobody else—I did not send for a second quantity of gin.
JAMES COLLINS . She came into the prison to me, and asked me what I meant to do about it, and brought me half a pound of meat and a loaf.

Witness. I took him some meat and a loaf—I was asked by Mrs. Collins's sister to go to the prison with her, as she was going to take him some victuals—I said I had no objection—she gave me half the victuals to take in a bason to Mr. Collins, while she took the other half to her sister, and in the prison both Mr. Collins and Kirtland begged me not to prosecute, and said his sister could make to all right with me, if I would go out of the way—I said I would not promise—when I got outside I was destitute of a

home—(the 2l., had been given me by a gentleman to relieve, and get a little girl out of the workhouse)—being destitute for three days and three nights in the street starving, I was induced by Mrs. Collin's sister and another friend of hers, to take a sovereign, saying there was no fear and they could not hurt me, I was to keep out of the way, and the rest I should have when they were acquitted; but since that I have been told of the damage I was in taking the money, and I was determined to come here on Saturday morning, had not the policeman met me on Friday night—the landlord and landlady of the Friar public-house were witnesses to my re ceiving the sovereign from Collins's sister.

Mary Collins, Q. Do you mean to swear I attempted to rob you?—Were we not dancing Jim Crow about the house, and, of course, you turned round and round with the dance? A. No, I did not—I did not lay on you bed—Mrs. Glenister did not say to me, "You faggot you have robbed me, nor did she strike me—she did not offer to strike me, to my know ledge—when I went to the station I certainly was not in a state to speak through the gin that was given me—I might be going round the room—do not dispute that—I have spoken nothing but the truth.

ELIZA GLENISTER . My real name is Eliza Gee; but I have been, un fortunately, living with a man, and have gone by his name, for six years—I was standing at my own door when Klrtland was going into Colline's with beer and gin in a mug—he asked me to go up—I said, "No, "but Mr. collins called me up, and I went—she asked me to sit down—I said I could not—she was in bed—she said, "Sit down, and I will get up—she went down, and fetched the prosecutrix up—when she came up, she asked her if the she would send for something to drink—she said, "Yes," and took out some money—she said, where was her gold—she looked into her hand, and I saw she had six half-crowns and one sovereign left—Mrs. Collines said "I must have that"—I said, "No, I shan't have that done when I am"—the prosecutrix went from the foot of the bed, and sat on a chair—Mrs. Collins went and sat by her aide, and tried, two or three times, to put her hand into her pocket, but I told her to let her alone—she pushed me down on a chair, and held me down by my arm, and tore my gown, and held me while (he other two took the prosecutrix into the next room—presently they came out, and said, "You may go in now"—I went into the room and Beattie said, "They have robbed me of all my money, "and on the flour laid some halfpence and half-a-crown—I asked them, several times, to give her money—Mrs. Collins told me to hold my tongue, and she would give me 5s.—I said I wanted the prosecutrix to have her money.

James Collins, Q. On the Sunday before this happened were you up in my room? A. I do not recollect—I might be—I did not say any thing about a bricklayer serving a warrant on you, and that if he did I would swear any thing for you.

James Collins. She is living now with a returned transport—she threw herself into the water once on account of a young man running after her Witness. That was about two years ago—I believe the man I live with was transported twelve or thirteen years ago—that was when he was a child and before I knew him.

Mary Collins. The prosecutrix lived with Mott of the custom-house robbery—she always comes up into my room when there is any thing to drink—it was Glenister robbed the woman, and she ought. to in my situation. Witness. I did not rob her.
James Collins. Q. Did not you say, "This is the person who cohabited with Mr. Mott?" and I said why I worked with her brother—1 said if I could
get a bit of a note from her it would be of service to me, as I work for Mott's brother, now in the docks. Witness, He did say so.

JOSEPH WILLEY . I am a policeman, I took the prisoners into custody. Mrs. Collins said, to Glenister before I took her, "If you hold your mouth it will be a good job for you—if you don't it will be a bad job, and you shall have your head smashed, if you split you will suffer for it—if you had had your regulars you would not have split"—I understand that to mean dividing the money between them.

Mary Collins Defence, I said, "Do you mean to say I robbed the woman?"—she said "No, I don't mean to say you did, but you took good care your husband and this man should"—I said, "If you say any thing to me I will smash your face"—it was because she did not have drink enough, that the words occurred between her and me.

MARY ANN LANE . I am a hat and bonnet box-maker, and live in Queen-street. I was in the room when the prisoner and prosecutrix were drinking—they were dancing, and singing, and at times acting part of a play—they seemed very much intoxicated, and had both gin and beer they asked me to sit down—I had not been there more than half an hour before a quarrel took place between the prosecutrix and Glenister—she charged Glenister with robbing her, and called her several names which I not think proper to mention—she said, "We have walked the streets many years together, do as you have done for the money and don't stairs and she would give her the money—the prosecutirx put her hand into her packet, took out some money, and scattered it all about the room—Mrs. Glenister took it up and put it into her pocket again—I came away, and left them quarreling—I don't know who took the money out afterwards.

GEORGE KIRTLAND . I am the prisoner's father—I saw these parties quarrelling about their money—the prosecutrix charged Glenister with robbing her—Glenister said, "Come down to the door and I will give you your money very speedily"—I thought it all a drunken spree, and walked away—I do not know what happened after—they were all drunk together.
(The prisoner Kirtland received a good character.)

JAMES COLLINS—
GUILTY . Aged 33.

MARY COLLINS—
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Confined Three Months.

KIRTLAND—
GUILTY . Aged 29.

2164.
HENRY WARE was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of April, 9 hats, value 4l. 10s.; and 9 hat-boxes, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
John Quincey Harris, his master; and
WILLIAM CLARKE
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c., to which Ware pleaded
GUILTY .
JOHN BOOKER . I am servant to Mr. Dempster, a pawnbroker, in Union-street, borough. I produce a hat which was pawned by the prisoner Clark. On the 22nd of June.

JOHN QUINCY HARRIS . I know this hat by a private mark inside—it was stolen out of my warehouse, and not sold—I did not miss it till the 31st of August, when Ware was detected, and we searched the pawn-brokers shops—I know nothing of Clarke—it is a new hat—Ware had an opportunity of taking it—we considered him trust worthy—he has been in our employ four years.
Clarke's Defence. I received it from Ware—he asked me to pawn it
for him, and said he would give me 3d. for it—he told me he bought them wholesale, and told his mother so too.
JOHN HENRY SMITH . I have a hat which was pawned by Clarke, on the 11th of July, for 3s.—he gave it in the name of "Henry Ware, 53, Ewer-street," and said it was his own property.

CLARKE—
NOT GUILTY .

2165.
HENRY WARE was again indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of January, 21 hats, value 10l.; and 21 hat-boxes, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
John Quincey Harris, his master; and
JANE WARE
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.; to which Henry Ware pleaded

GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years.
WILLIAM WRIGHT . The prisoner Henry was in the employ of Mr. Harris—the other prisoner is his mother—she knew he was in our employ—I never saw her near our place.

JOHN BOOKER . I am shopman to Mr. Dempster, pawnbroker, Union street, Borough. I produce some hats—I can identify the female prisoner as pawning one of them on the 11th of May—she said it belonged to her son—she did not describe who he was—I advanced 4s. on it.

JAMES LOCKYER . I am servant to Mr. Morrison, of Blackfriars-road. On the 10th of March the female prisoner pawned a hat at our shop, an other on the 10th of April, another on the 9th of June, and another on the 9th of May—the first she brought I took no notice of—when she brought the next, I said, "Did not I take a hat of you before?"—she said, "Yes, it was a hat my son bought—it did not fit him, and he sold the duplicate"—I thought the other hats might be the same one redeemed, and taken in again, but I found we had four in our possession afterwards.
JOHN QUINCEY HARRIS . The female prisoner knew her son was living with me, and that I was hatter by trade.
SOPHIA COLE . I produce a hat which the female prisoner pawned on the 2nd of March, for 5s.—she said she brought it from her son—I live in Waterloo-road.

JOSEPH PARKER . I live with Mr. Dickens, of Lambeth-marsh. I have a hat which was pawned in February, for 3s.—I cannot swear it was by the female prisoner, but I have known her bringing hats, for the last three months, repeatedly, and I have refused to take them in.

Jane Ware's Defence. My son brought them home, and told me he bought them wholesale, and paid so much a-week out of his wages—I said, "If you got them dishonestly, tell me the truth"—he said, "Mother, I got them honestly.

MR. HARRIS re-examined. We now and then let our people take out hats to sell on their own account, but it is not our common practice—it is not likely out of the prisoner's earnings of 7s. a week he could pay it—she knew he had only 7s. a week—we did not board him—he lived with his mother, and she boarded him—the hats are worth 10s. each, cost price—he has had about two hats from me in six or eight months, and paid for them at 2s. a week.

JANE WARE—
GUILTY . Aged 50.—
Confined Twelve Months.
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2166.
NICHOLAS WALKER was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of September, 3 wooden staves, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
James Thomas Barker.

GEORGE CHARLES PEACH . I am foreman to James Thomas Barker, of St. Savionr's Dock, in the parish of St. Saviour. We have lost many staves lately—about two o'clock, on the 14th of September, from information, I went after the prisoner, and overtook him in Redcross-street, and found on him three staves—I told him I had caught him at last—he said, "Will you swear to the staves?"—I told him I would—he said, "Will you swear I have not paid for them?"—I said I would swear he should go to the station-house—the policeman came up at the moment and I gave him into custody—I know the prisoner from his occasionally dealing at the yard for a stave at a time, but not for staves of this description—they are worth 3s. 6d.

Prisoner. I went into this yard, went into the stable, and asked him to serve me three small staves—I had but 2s.—I said I would give him the rest when I came by again, and the carman came to let me have the three staves—his name is Welch—I have dealt at that yard four years—the carman boy was coming in at the time I came out with them.
WILLIAM WELCH . I am carman to Mr. Barker. The prisoner occasionally deals there—I did not sell him either of these three staves.

Prisoner. Q. Did I come into the stable while you were cutting a stick across? A. No, I did not see you till I was at Union Hall—he has not bought any staves the last six months—I never sold him this sort of staves—only six-foot staves.

Prisoner. Welch may deny that I had bought them when he had not the full money—I gave him 2s., and was to give the rest afterwards—he has often obliged me before by letting me have staves when I wanted 1d., or 2d., or 4d. Witness. I never trusted any man a farthing—I never put 1d. or 2d. to his money, and gave it to my master—I was in the stable, cut ting a stick, but I did not see him—if I had he would have been stopped directly.

GEORGE CHARLES PEACH
