re-examined. I took him about ten minutes past two o'clock—he said, would I swear he had not paid for them—the carman was there, but he is not allowed to sell—staves when I am in the yard—he would not have known the price of these.
HENRY THOMAS PEACH . I saw the prisoner come out of the gateway with three staves—I did not see Welch at that time—he was at the stable.
Prisoner. They might tell him to say what they wished—I met him in the street, with a pot of beer in his hand.

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined One Year; Three Months Solitary.

2167.
JAMES FAITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of September 6 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Thomas Wall; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Three Days; and
Whipped.

2168.
ROBERT HAYNES was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of July, 1 shawl, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Brooks.

THOMAS BROOKS . I live in High-street, Southwark, and am a linen draper. The prisoner was in my employ as porter—it was not his duty to attend to the shop, but he was left in the back part of it occasionally—I have not missed this shawl in particular, but I have missed several things from the warehouse—I know this shawl is similar to what I have in my warehouse—I have sold several of them—I believe this to be mine.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. What time did the prisoner first come into your service? A. Three weeks or a month before the 14th of

July, and he continued about a month after that—he did not leave me—I had him taken while he was in my employ—he was out of my service about a week after the 14th of July, I think—I do not know whether he was taken a week after he left me—he had left me, and came back again—he was employed at so much a-week—I can swear he was in my ser vice for a month—I think it was about a week after the 14th of July that he was taken—on the 13th of September, I think—I think he was employed for a fortnight together after the 14th of July—I cannot say when he came back to my service—he had been about a month in my service on the 14th of July—I should think he came about the beginning of June—he left, and came back in about a week or ten days—he was discharged because we did not require him—that was about the middle of August—I was not the person who dismissed him. and do not know when he left me—I know that he was discharged, and taken the second time—I ✗ not miss any article while he was with me the first time, till I received information—I have fourteen or fifteen persons in my employ—some of them have been discharged, but I think I could find every one of them—it was the prisoner's duty to carry out parcels—it was his duty to be ✗ almost the whole day—I have seen him in the warehouse four or five times by himself, and made a remark that he ought not to have been there—he was waiting there for the traveller—as far as I can judge, this is the property I have missed, it is not at all an uncommon shawl—we have several of this pattern—I cannot say it has not been sold.

GEORGE OSBORNE . I am a labourer, and attend at a skittle-ground On the evening of the 14th of July the prisoner was there—he offered as sell me a shawl like this—I bought it, and gave it to my wife to wear—I gave 7s. 6d. for this shawl, with some lawn, and two handkerchiefs—I took it to Mr. Brooks when I heard of this.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you known this boy very long? A. I should think about twelve months—I knew a little boy of the name of Goodwin—at the time of buying this shawl he came over to me, and asked me to buy the things, and said he picked them up in Blackman street—I bought it all for 7s. 6d.—I did not know the value of them—I never said, at any time, that I gave 1s. for the shawl—nor 1s. 3d.—I paid the money to the prisoner—I did not go and inquire the value of it—I thought it worth 7s. 6d.—I never bought a shawl before from Goodwin—I did not say so before the Magistrate—I did not buy the lawn at my own house, but at the skittle-ground.
JAMES REYNOLDS (police-constable M 66.) I took the prisoner, I found 2s. on him, and the keys of the stable.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you ask him what he knew about some silk stockings? A. No—he asked me what I wanted with him—I said I had information that he had stolen some silk stockings.
NOT GUILTY .
Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2169.
WILLIAM BURN was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of July, 2 wheels, value 4l. 10s., the goods of
James Eagle and another; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months; Three Weeks Solitary.

2170.
THOMAS SEYMOUR was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
SUSAN TURNER . My master keeps the Feathers, public-house in

Lambeth-walk. On Wednesday, the 6th of last month, the prisoner came to the bar for a pint of porter, about half-past seven o'clock at night—he gave me a shilling—I gave him 10 1/2 d. change—I put the shilling under the foot of a glass, but I put it into the till when I took it of the prisoner, and then took it out—there was no other shilling there, only one sixpence—I looked at it directly the prisoner left, and saw it was a bad one—I marked it—the next morning, (Thursday,) the prisoner came again, between eight and nine o'clock, for a pint of porter—he gave me a shilling—I said it was bad—he said it was not—I told him he had been there the night before—he said he had not—I went round to him—Mr. Carins, my master, was there—I am sure the prisoner is the person who came the night before—I gave the second shilling to my master, then went and fetched the other than I had marked and put under the glass—I gave that to Henry Brackstone.

GEORGE CARINS . I keep the Feathers. I heard the dispute between the barmaid and the prisoner—I came out from where I was at breakfast, and saw the prisoner going out of the door—the bad shilling laid on the counter—the barmaid took it up and gave it to me—I went for a police-officer—I did nor receive more than one shilling from her, and I gave it to the policeman, with another which I got from Brackstone—the prisoner was searched, and nothing found on him.
HENRY BRACKSTONE . I am barman to Mr. Carins. I got the shilling from the barmaid, and gave it to Mr. Carins.

WILLIAM BOLD (police-constable L 24.) I received these two shillings from Mr. Carins—I took the prisoner, and asked if he had any home—he said, "None whatever"—I asked him where he worked—he said he was out of work; that he had been working at the other side of Vauxhall-bridge, at an iron foundry—I found nothing on him.
JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. These are both counterfeit, and from the same mould.

Prisoner's Defence. I went there in the evening, and had a pint of beer, but I am certain it was not a bad shilling—the next morning I went and offered a shilling, she said that I had been the night before, and given a bad shilling—she ran round and stopped me—on the Wednesday night I was coming over Westminster-bridge, and a woman coming over asked me to carry a bundle, and she gave me the shilling, and the next one was one that was given to me.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Year; Three Months Solitary.
Before Mr. Common Serjeant.

2171.
HENRY CLOWSLEY was indicted
for embezzlement.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

ELIZABETH ELLIOTT . I am housekeeper to Mr. Cubitt, at Clapham, he is a customer to Mr. Terry, the butcher. I know the prisoner—Mr. Cubitt had his bills weekly—the prisoner used to bring them, and I paid him a week after—when the bills were paid, they were delivered to him to get receipted by his master, and bring back again—the prisoner put "paid" himself to this bill of 1l. 10s. 5d.—the date of the last item is the 19th of August—I paid it the prisoner on the 22nd—on the 12th of September I paid the prisoner two bills of 1l. 16s. 5d. and 9s. 3d., making in the whole 2l. 5s. 8d.—I gave him the bills to get receipted—I asked him for them—he said it was all right, and he would bring the 4d. change—the next morning I had some suspicion, and inquired of Mr. Terry the next day.
Prisoner. I paid the 2l. 6s. to my master.

WILLIAM TERRY . I am a butcher, at Clapham. The prisoner was in my service—he was in the habit of receiving money on my account—✗ was always a rule laid down to him, to take the money and bring the bills to me, or his mistress to write the receipt, and take them back—it was his duty to pay me the money—Mr. Cubitt was a customer—the prisoner did not account to me for 1l. 10s. 5d., paid on the 10th of August—he paid the sum of 2l. 5s. 8d. after I challenged him with it in my own house, he gave me two sovereigns, two half-crowns, and two sixpences, and I found the bills in his cart.
Prisoner. The 1l. 10s. 5d. I spent—I paid away some money to my club.
GUILTY . Aged 20.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.
Confined Three Months; Three Weeks Solitary.
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2172.
FANNY REED was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of August 2 handkerchiefs, value 6s.; and 2 towels, value 1s.; the goods of
James Bannatts James.

JAMES BANNATTS JAMES . I am a mariner, and belong to the Exchange of St. Ives. On the 28th of August she was lying in Alderman's tier—I had been at Waterford, and there by accident I met the prisoner—I took her on board, and she was three weeks on board—I had some business on shore, and left her the key of the state room—I returned at half-past eleven o'clock at night, and then she was gone, and the state room was locked—I waited, and she did not come—I dropped asleep, and the next morning I broke open the door and found my drawers were all open, and this property and some Irish notes gone—I heard she had gone off for Cork—I came to London, and found her lodgings, and went for an officer and found this property in her box—one of my towels has my name on it—the other has not.

Prisoner. The handkerchief he gave me, and the towels were put in with them—he said he intended to marry me, but I found he had a wife at St. Ives, and I left him—he had promised me marriage. Witness. I am married—my wife is in London now.

JOHN WOODHOUSE . I am a police-sergeant. I found the prisoner in Unicorn-square, Tooley-street—the prosecutor pointed her out—before I opened her box I found the two towels and handkerchief—she said she knew nothing about any of them—she did not then say that he gave them to her.

Prisoner. The handkerchief he gave me—I met him in a public house, and he said he should like to be with me—he took me on board his vessel and kept me better than three weeks, and told every one that I was his wife—I found he was going after another woman, and then I left him—I took my things, but I did not know it—the handkerchiefs he gave me, and he might know that, as I wore them all the time I was in the ship.

JAMES BANNATTS JAMES (re-examined.) She had things on board which she kept in the state room, but not in the drawers—I had my key—I did not sleep in the state room while she was there—I never slept with her—when I came on board at eleven o'clock at night the state room door was locked—I slept in the cabin that night—I do not know where I should have passed the night if I had found it all right—I was very drunk—when there is no female I sleep in the state room—I kept her on board as
a matter of charity—she told me she was a servant girl—I gave her ✗ the state room—my intention was to take her to London as a passenger.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2173.
ROBERT LOCKIE and
JOHN BEAGLE were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of September, 1 coat, value 8s., the goods of
William Poole.

WILLIAM POOLE . I went with a hired horse with Mr. Moseley to Camberwell, to assist him with his dray—I stopped at a beer-shop at the corner of Lock's-fields—I left my coat in the dray, when we went to fetch the empty barrels out, about nine o'clock in the evening of the 18th of September—I was there about ten minutes—when I came out my coat was gone—this is it—I made inquiry about it, and had a direction to the prisoner's house I went and saw them there—I cannot swear to Beagle, but I can to Lockie—I said they had got my coat in their possession, and I demanded it—Lockie said there was not such a thing there—there was a woman there—she said there was such a thing there, and she brought it to me from behind Lockie's chair—it was mine—I should think that was half an hour after my missing it—the policeman then came, and said, if he took them up would I give charge of them, I said "Yes," and took them during the night—they had made their escape out of the back door.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Where did Lockie run from? A. He ran out of his back door—my mate said he would give them a good sound thumping.

GEORGE PANKHOUSE . I am a green-grocer. I was at the beer-shop about nine o'clock, and saw Beagle take the coat off the dray—I am sure he was the person—I had known him before—Lockie was with him—Beagle went away with it, and Lockie with him—I had seen them together before.

Cross-examined. Q. On what side was it? A. On the right-hand side—the off-side—I was standing at my father's door, on the near side of the dray—it had butts of beer on it—I can swear it was Beagle took it—there were not many persons standing there.
(The prisoner Beagle received a good character.)

LOCKIE—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

BEAGLE—
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
Confined Three Months; Three Weeks Solitary.

2174.
THOMAS HILL was indicted for
feloniously uttering a request for the delivery of two sheets of 8lbs. weight of lead, with intent to defraud
Thomas Ross and another; and
JAMES ADAMS
as accessory before the fact; and
THOMAS MURRAY
as accessory after the fact.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

HENRY ALLAN . I am the owner of vans and carts, and live in Great Wild-street, Drury-lane. On the morning of the 21st of August, Adams and Hill came to me to hire a van—A lams asked if I had got a van to let—I told him I had—he asked me what for—I said, "1s. 6d. an hour"—he said, "I want it"—I said, "You shall have it directly it comes home,"

and they had it—Hill said they were going to Tooley-street—they were in a great hurry, particularly Adams—it was gone three hours—I sent my man Parsons with it—I think it was between three and four o'clock, but I will not be certain.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Do you know a person of the name of Williams? A. I do not know him—I have heard talk of him since this—neither of the men that came about the van spoke of him—a short stout man was with them—they say his name was Williams—I do not know what has become of him—they all came together—Adams appeared to act as the master.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. I suppose you had no opportunity of knowing, but from what they said, who was master? A. No—the short stout man did not speak, to the beat of my knowledge—they were all close together.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Adams asked for the van? A. Yes—he seemed in a greater hurry than the other men.

WILLIAM PARSONS . I drove this van, and went just by Tooley-street, to Mr. Bloyd, the lead-merchant, in Union-street, Southwark-Hill went with me—Adams went as far as Lincoln's Inn-fields—he then left, and Hill went on with me—when I got to Mr. Bloyd's, a sheet of Lead was put into the van and we drove up to Murray's stable, which runs into Crown street, St. Giles's—Hill went with me, and Adams was waiting there for us—the lead was taken out of the van, and put into Murray's stable—both of them helped to take it out, and Adams paid me two half-crowns—he said, "There is 6d. for yourself and 4s. 6d. for your master"—on the following day, (Tuesday,) I went to the same place, and after that I went to a person of the name of Walker—Hill was with me, and he was then taken into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Mr. Ross was there then? A. Yes, I was there when Hill was taken into custody—he did not say that Adams was the man who employed him and that he knew where he was—I heard him say that Adams was at a public-house—I did not hear him say that he was employed by anybody.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Was Adams there? A. No—my master's is about three minutes' walk from Lincoln's Inn-fields—no other man was with them inside my master's yard—no one besides Adams and Hill went to Lincoln's Inn-fields—I then went on, Adams leaving me—Hill got up into the van—I do not know whether he was the active man—he rode with me after the lead.

MR. BODKIN. Q. What did Adams say? A. He said that his master was waiting at the public-house for him—he said the name of his master, and then he went to see if he could see him, and he was not there—the policeman went with him, and then he came back again to Mr. Ross.

JOHN CHAMBERS . I am clerk to Joseph Bloyd, a lead-merchant, at No. 11, Duke-street, Southwark. Messrs. Ross, the builders, are customers of his—I know they were employed in August at some buildings at Knights bridge—on the 21st of August the prisoner Hill came to my master's warehouse, in Duke-street, and delivered this request to me—I examined it, and said to Hill, "The middle of the order does not appear to be Mr. Ross's handwriting"—Hill said, "Yes, it is"—I turned over the order, and saw at the back of it part of Mr. Ross's address—I was in the habit of receiving from Mr. Ross orders on the backs of letters—(reads) "August

21, 1837—Mr. Bloyd, please let the bearer have two sheets 8lbs. lead—Thomas Ross"—I had only one sheet and told Hill so—he said he would take the one, and he had better take another of a different size to make up the lead—he told me it was wanted for the job at Knights bridge, for the bottoms of the cisterns—I delivered him one sheet of 8lbs. lead, value 16l. 1s. 11d.—I delivered him a weight note of it, addressed to Messrs. T. and G. Ross—it contained a description and weight of the lead, and from whom it came—Hill had a man waiting to receive it—Hill said he had better take another sheet to make up his load, that it would be wanted for the lining of the cisterns—Mr. Thomas Ross came the next day, and I gave him information.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. This note is written in pencil? A. Yes—the body of it did not appear to be Mr. Ross's handwriting—the signature appeared to me to be a different hand—the body of the order was writ ten in a shaky hand—upon his saying it was Mr. Ross's, and seeing the address on the back, I considered it to be authentic—I know this to be the same paper as was presented to me by Hill, by my initials on the corner, which I put when I received it back at Union-hall—I had put no mark on it before.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. This endorsement on the back, "T. Ross, Esq., Bl., induced you to think it was genuine? A. Yes.

THOMAS ROSS . I live at Blackheath. In August I was engaged with my brother in building some houses at Knightsbridge—I occasionally purchased lead of Mr. Bloyd—Adams was employed by me at these buildings at Knightsbridge, as a man to put on the lead, and Hill was employed by Adams—I rode up to town very early on Tuesday morning, the 22nd of August, and went to Mr. Walker's—after making inquiries of Mr. Bloyd, this order was shown to me—when I got to Walker's I did not find Hill—he came in a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes with a sheet of lead in a cart—Parsons was driving it—I said to Hill, "You have been doing something wrong, you have been forging an order; what became of the sheet of lead you took from Mr. Bloyd's yesterday?"—he said, "We have taken it to the job at Knightsbridge"—I said, "I was there very late last evening, and saw no lead there: and I never ordered any 8lbs. lead, we never use it, and the order you gave was a forgery"—he said, "Let me run to Adams, as he was to have met me"—I said, "You must stop where you are"—I sent for a constable, and he was taken to the station-house—after that I made a search after Adams, and found him, after considerable search, at the Crown public-house, in Stanhope-street, Clare-market—he was told what he was charged with—he said, "I am innocent"—Hennessy, the officer, took him—he said he was not guilty of taking any lead, he had nothing to do with it—he was then taken to the same station-house as Hill was—after that I went, from information I had received, to Murray's shop—I know nothing more of this transaction, but what was stated to me by Murray—I had some conversation with a clerk of Mr. Riley's—I did not charge Murray, but the Magistrate held him to bail.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Was Adams a labourer, or did he work on his own account? A. He had so much a ton for laying the lead down, and he was to employ whom he pleased to assist him—Hill was no servant of mine, but his—Adams had applied to me for money shortly be fore this occurred, on account of the contract, on the Saturday night previous I refused to give it him—he had no other person in his employ but Hill, that I am aware of—I do not know Williams—I deposed before

the Magistrate what I said when I saw Hill come with the cart, and what I said was taken down I suppose—I signed it, and it was read over to me—I did not say, "Hill said that he believed it was gone to the job at Knightsbridge"—he said it a dozen times, sometimes singular and some times plural, "I have taken it" and" We have taken it"—I said, "You have been doing something wrong, the order you took was a forgery"—he said, "1 know nothing of it, but I will run and bring my master, Mr. Adams, who is at the public-house at the comer."

MR. CLARKSOK. Q. Were you in the habit of writing your requests on the backs of letters, and so on? A. It is very likely, I write sometimes in ink, but mostly with a pencil—this order is not my writing—I have never used 81bs. lead—I should certainly say Hill knew that—I did not authorise Hill or Adams to get lead from Mr. Bloyd, and carry it to the stable of Murray.

DANIEL HENNESSY (police-constable L 171.) On the 22nd of August Hill was brought to the station-house—I afterwards took Adams into custody, from the Crown public-house, Stanhope-street, Clare-market—when Adams and Hill were together, Hill said he received the order from Adams, and Adams said he did not know any thing of Hill nor of the order—Hill told Mr. Ross that he took the lead to Knightsbridge for the job, to be sure.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN Q. Did he say, "We took it"?—I did not hear him say that—I heard him say it only once, at the station house, in the presence of Mr. Ross and the Inspector—I did not hear him say, "I believe it was taken."
JOHN FITZGERALD (police-constable L 124.) I went to the stable, and found the lead.

JOHN CHAMERS
re-examined. That is the lead which I gave to Hill, when he produced the request to me.

HILL—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.
Confined Two Years.

ADAMS—
GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Transported for Seven Years.

MURRAY—
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2176.
THOMAS DAVIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of June, 6 looking-glass stands, value 6s.; 14 pillars, value 7s.; 6 side-screws, value 9d.; and 8 ball feet, value 6d.; the goods of
John Austen, his master.

JOHN AUSTEN . I am a cabinet-maker, and live in Webber-street, West minster-road. The prisoner worked for me as journeyman nearly two years—he rented an apartment in my house—the principal he did was looking-glass work; I took some heavier work to do, and he left of his own accord—about two months afterwards I saw some work of mine at Mr. Helsden's, and knew it—this is it—it is in an unfinished state—I had two pairs of these pillars turned as long ago as November twelve months—this one has been altered since it was stolen, but it corresponds with this other one which I have, and they are badly done—I reprimanded my apprentice for doing this bad work.

WILLIAM HELSDEN . I am a carver and gilder, and live at Newington Causeway. These frames were found in my possession—the prisoner called with one of them on the 18th of August, and stated that I should have that and three more, and two less, at a price—I agreed to purchase them—he
brought them, and said he should have a larger one, which I should have for a little more—I agreed to have them, knowing him as in Mr. Austen's employ—I bought them on the 19th of August.

GEORGE AIKERMAN . I am the apprentice. There is one of these trays which my master told me of when the prisoner was working the same morning—he said it was bad work—I can swear to this one—my master had not sold it.
Prisoner. There is a piece jointed on this. Witness. There is no piece jointed on this.

JOHN AUSTEN
re-examined. I did not miss these for two months—the bottoms were taken in a separate state, and the pillars were taken in a separate state—they have been put together since they were taken, quite in a rough state—if a pillar were taken from the stand it would correspond with this mould.

Prisoner. I have taken patterns of his moulds to cut my work by—I have not done a stroke of work for him since the week before Easter—I was laid up with the gout in my hands—here is a portion of wood that I cut the bottoms off—I have a witness here who helped me to make them.
THOMAS HIGGINS . I assisted the prisoner to make these—he made six small bottoms, and three large ones—there was a fault in one of them and he filled it up with putty.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, OCTOBER 23rd, 1837.
